questions.question: Change from active to passive voice: 'Mohan sells fresh vegetables.'
questions.answer: Fresh vegetables are sold by Mohan.
questions.explanation: Simple present active (V1) becomes passive with is/am/are + V3. The object 'fresh vegetables' becomes the subject.

questions.question: Change from active to passive voice: 'The customers like the vegetables.'
questions.answer: The vegetables are liked by the customers.
questions.explanation: Simple present: 'like' (V1) becomes 'are liked' (are + V3). Object becomes subject.

questions.question: Change from active to passive voice: 'Mohan buys vegetables from the market.'
questions.answer: Vegetables are bought by Mohan from the market.
questions.explanation: Simple present: 'buys' becomes 'are bought'. The prepositional phrase 'from the market' remains at the end.

questions.question: Change from active to passive voice: 'His father teaches him the trade.'
questions.answer: He is taught the trade by his father.
questions.explanation: With two objects (indirect: him, direct: the trade), the indirect object becomes the subject in passive.

questions.question: Change from active to passive voice: 'The mouse chased the lizard.'
questions.answer: The lizard was chased by the mouse.
questions.explanation: Simple past: 'chased' (V2) becomes 'was chased' (was + V3).

questions.question: Change from active to passive voice: 'Megha will buy a new car tomorrow.'
questions.answer: A new car will be bought by Megha tomorrow.
questions.explanation: Simple future: 'will buy' becomes 'will be bought' (will + be + V3).

questions.question: Change from active to passive voice: 'Father will teach me how to drive a car.'
questions.answer: I will be taught how to drive a car by Father.
questions.explanation: Simple future with indirect object: 'me' becomes the subject 'I' in passive voice.

questions.question: Change from active to passive voice: 'The children will sing many songs.'
questions.answer: Many songs will be sung by the children.
questions.explanation: Simple future: 'will sing' becomes 'will be sung' (will + be + V3).

questions.question: Change from active to passive voice (present continuous): 'We are watching the sunset.'
questions.answer: The sunset is being watched by us.
questions.explanation: Present continuous: 'are watching' becomes 'is being watched' (is/am/are + being + V3).

questions.question: Change from active to passive voice (present continuous): 'Anuj and Rohit are taking pictures.'
questions.answer: Pictures are being taken by Anuj and Rohit.
questions.explanation: Present continuous: 'are taking' becomes 'are being taken'.

questions.question: Change from active to passive voice (present continuous): 'The guide is carrying a heavy bag.'
questions.answer: A heavy bag is being carried by the guide.
questions.explanation: Present continuous: 'is carrying' becomes 'is being carried'.

questions.question: Change from active to passive voice (present continuous): 'They are drinking hot tea.'
questions.answer: Hot tea is being drunk by them.
questions.explanation: Present continuous: 'are drinking' becomes 'is being drunk'. Note: 'drunk' is the V3 of 'drink'.

questions.question: Change from active to passive voice (present continuous): 'He is distributing brochures to all the tourists.'
questions.answer: Brochures are being distributed to all the tourists by him.
questions.explanation: Present continuous: 'is distributing' becomes 'are being distributed'.

questions.question: Change from active to passive voice (present continuous): 'We are not eating any pastries.'
questions.answer: No pastries are being eaten by us.
questions.explanation: Negative present continuous: 'are not eating' becomes 'are being eaten'. Note: 'not...any' in active voice becomes 'no' in passive voice.

questions.question: Change from active to passive voice (present continuous): 'We are enjoying the view from the mountain peak.'
questions.answer: The view from the mountain peak is being enjoyed by us.
questions.explanation: Present continuous: 'are enjoying' becomes 'is being enjoyed'.

questions.question: Change from active to passive voice (present continuous): 'A tourist guide is helping us to locate the most beautiful spots.'
questions.answer: We are being helped by a tourist guide to locate the most beautiful spots.
questions.explanation: Present continuous: 'is helping' becomes 'are being helped'. The indirect object 'us' becomes the subject 'We'.

questions.question: Change from active to passive voice (present perfect): 'The thieves have taken away all the money.'
questions.answer: All the money has been taken away by the thieves.
questions.explanation: Present perfect: 'have taken' becomes 'has been taken' (has/have + been + V3).

questions.question: Change from active to passive voice (present perfect): 'The police have located the place where the thieves are hiding.'
questions.answer: The place where the thieves are hiding has been located by the police.
questions.explanation: Present perfect: 'have located' becomes 'has been located'. The relative clause remains unchanged.

questions.question: Change from active to passive voice (present perfect): 'The thieves have hidden the money in the cave.'
questions.answer: The money has been hidden in the cave by the thieves.
questions.explanation: Present perfect: 'have hidden' becomes 'has been hidden'.

questions.question: Change from active to passive voice (present perfect): 'The police have called a detective to help them.'
questions.answer: A detective has been called by the police to help them.
questions.explanation: Present perfect: 'have called' becomes 'has been called'.

questions.question: Change from active to passive voice (present perfect): 'The detective has found a way to reach the gang of thieves.'
questions.answer: A way to reach the gang of thieves has been found by the detective.
questions.explanation: Present perfect: 'has found' becomes 'has been found'.

questions.question: Change from active to passive voice (present perfect): 'He has taken the police to a village.'
questions.answer: The police have been taken to a village by him.
questions.explanation: Present perfect: 'has taken' becomes 'have been taken'. Note: 'police' takes plural verb.

questions.question: Change from active to passive voice (present perfect): 'The people of the village have set up a trap for the gang.'
questions.answer: A trap for the gang has been set up by the people of the village.
questions.explanation: Present perfect: 'have set up' becomes 'has been set up'.

questions.question: Change from active to passive voice (present perfect): 'Finally, the police have arrested the gang.'
questions.answer: Finally, the gang has been arrested by the police.
questions.explanation: Present perfect: 'have arrested' becomes 'has been arrested'.

questions.question: Change from active to passive voice (future perfect): 'This school will have celebrated the silver jubilee next year.'
questions.answer: The silver jubilee will have been celebrated by this school next year.
questions.explanation: Future perfect: 'will have celebrated' becomes 'will have been celebrated' (will + have + been + V3).

questions.question: Change from active to passive voice (future perfect): 'It will have admitted more students.'
questions.answer: More students will have been admitted by it.
questions.explanation: Future perfect: 'will have admitted' becomes 'will have been admitted'.

questions.question: Change from active to passive voice (future perfect): 'It will have offered more courses of study.'
questions.answer: More courses of study will have been offered by it.
questions.explanation: Future perfect: 'will have offered' becomes 'will have been offered'.

questions.question: Change from active to passive voice (future perfect): 'Many students will have taken the public examinations.'
questions.answer: The public examinations will have been taken by many students.
questions.explanation: Future perfect: 'will have taken' becomes 'will have been taken'.

questions.question: Change from active to passive voice (future perfect): 'They will have scored good grades.'
questions.answer: Good grades will have been scored by them.
questions.explanation: Future perfect: 'will have scored' becomes 'will have been scored'.

questions.question: Change from active to passive voice (future perfect): 'The principal will have felicitated the students.'
questions.answer: The students will have been felicitated by the principal.
questions.explanation: Future perfect: 'will have felicitated' becomes 'will have been felicitated'.

questions.question: Change from active to passive voice (future perfect): 'The school will have earned a good reputation in the town.'
questions.answer: A good reputation in the town will have been earned by the school.
questions.explanation: Future perfect: 'will have earned' becomes 'will have been earned'.

questions.question: Change from active to passive voice (future perfect): 'The district administration will have honoured the school management.'
questions.answer: The school management will have been honoured by the district administration.
questions.explanation: Future perfect: 'will have honoured' becomes 'will have been honoured'.

questions.question: Change from passive to active voice: 'The necklace was being admired by all the customers.'
questions.answer: All the customers were admiring the necklace.
questions.explanation: Past continuous passive 'was being admired' becomes active 'were admiring'.

questions.question: Change from passive to active voice: 'The poem has been recited very eloquently by Promila.'
questions.answer: Promila has recited the poem very eloquently.
questions.explanation: Present perfect passive 'has been recited' becomes active 'has recited'.

questions.question: Change from passive to active voice: 'The house may be vacated by Suraj.'
questions.answer: Suraj may vacate the house.
questions.explanation: Modal passive 'may be vacated' becomes active 'may vacate'.

questions.question: Change from passive to active voice: 'The criminal will have been acquitted by the judge by now.'
questions.answer: The judge will have acquitted the criminal by now.
questions.explanation: Future perfect passive 'will have been acquitted' becomes active 'will have acquitted'.

questions.question: Change from passive to active voice: 'Let not parents be taken for granted.'
questions.answer: Let us not take parents for granted.
questions.explanation: Imperative passive becomes active with an implied subject like 'us'.

questions.question: Change from passive to active voice: 'The trees in this neighbourhood should not be cut down.'
questions.answer: We/People should not cut down the trees in this neighbourhood.
questions.explanation: Modal passive 'should not be cut down' becomes active with a general subject like 'We' or 'People'.

questions.question: Change from passive to active voice: 'The author has been appreciated for the story's intricate plot.'
questions.answer: People/Readers have appreciated the author for the story's intricate plot.
questions.explanation: When 'by + agent' is missing, use a general subject like 'People' or 'Readers'.

questions.question: Change from passive to active voice: 'Such an excuse can never be accepted.'
questions.answer: We/One can never accept such an excuse.
questions.explanation: Modal passive 'can never be accepted' becomes active with a general subject.

questions.question: Identify the voice: 'Ria reads the newspaper.'
questions.answer: Active voice
questions.explanation: The subject 'Ria' performs the action of reading. The verb 'reads' is in active voice.

questions.question: Identify the voice: 'A story is told by Rubina.'
questions.answer: Passive voice
questions.explanation: The subject 'A story' receives the action. The verb 'is told' is in passive voice.

questions.question: What is a transitive verb?
questions.answer: A transitive verb is a verb that has an object. For example, in 'Ria reads the newspaper', 'reads' is transitive because it has an object 'the newspaper'.
questions.explanation: Transitive verbs transfer action from the subject to an object. Only transitive verbs can be changed from active to passive voice.

questions.question: Why can't intransitive verbs be changed to passive voice?
questions.answer: Intransitive verbs cannot be changed to passive voice because they do not have an object. The passive voice requires an object to become the new subject.
questions.explanation: For example, 'She sleeps' cannot be made passive because 'sleeps' has no object.

questions.question: Change from active to passive voice: 'The teacher praised the students.'
questions.answer: The students were praised by the teacher.
questions.explanation: Simple past: 'praised' (V2) becomes 'were praised' (were + V3).

questions.question: Change from active to passive voice: 'Someone has stolen my wallet.'
questions.answer: My wallet has been stolen (by someone).
questions.explanation: Present perfect: 'has stolen' becomes 'has been stolen'. 'By someone' is often omitted when the agent is unknown.

questions.question: Change from active to passive voice: 'They are building a new bridge.'
questions.answer: A new bridge is being built by them.
questions.explanation: Present continuous: 'are building' becomes 'is being built'.

questions.question: Change from active to passive voice: 'The committee will announce the results tomorrow.'
questions.answer: The results will be announced by the committee tomorrow.
questions.explanation: Simple future: 'will announce' becomes 'will be announced'.

questions.question: Change from passive to active voice: 'The letter was written by my sister.'
questions.answer: My sister wrote the letter.
questions.explanation: Simple past passive 'was written' becomes active 'wrote'.

questions.question: Change from passive to active voice: 'The cake is being baked by mother.'
questions.answer: Mother is baking the cake.
questions.explanation: Present continuous passive 'is being baked' becomes active 'is baking'.
